articles.headline: U.S. Accuses Google of Abusing Monopoly in Ad Technology
articles.snippet: The Justice Department’s antitrust lawsuit, which a group of states joined, was the fifth by U.S. officials against the company since 2020.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department’s antitrust lawsuit, which a group of states joined, was the fifth by U.S. officials against the company since 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and a group of eight states sued Google on Tuesday, accusing it of illegally abusing a monopoly over the technology that powers online advertising, in the agency’s first antitrust lawsuit against a tech giant under President Biden and an escalation in legal pressure on one of the world’s biggest internet companies.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Nico Grant

articles.headline: Biden’s Handling of Secret Documents Complicates the Case Against Trump
articles.snippet: The cases are markedly different in their particulars. But they are similar enough that as a practical matter, Democrats will have a hard time using the issue against former President Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: The cases are markedly different in their particulars. But they are similar enough that as a practical matter, Democrats will have a hard time using the issue against former President Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. agents are rummaging through President Biden’s private home. Republicans are on the attack. Democrats are reluctant to defend him. Lawyers are being hired. Witnesses are being interviewed. The press secretary is being pelted with questions she cannot or will not answer.

articles.headline: Murdoch Backtracks on Plan to Merge His Media Empire
articles.snippet: News Corp, one of his companies, said Rupert Murdoch had determined that a merger was “not optimal for shareholders of News Corp and Fox at this time.”
articles.abstract: News Corp, one of his companies, said Rupert Murdoch had determined that a merger was “not optimal for shareholders of News Corp and Fox at this time.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch has halted his plans to combine the two parts of his media empire.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch, Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: U.S. Plans to Send Abrams Tanks to Ukraine, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The Biden administration had resisted sending tanks, which Ukraine says it needs, but the move is seen as likely to push Germany to approve the transfer of its own tanks.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration had resisted sending tanks, which Ukraine says it needs, but the move is seen as likely to push Germany to approve the transfer of its own tanks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Reversing its longstanding resistance, the Biden administration plans to send M1 Abrams tanks to Ukraine, U.S. officials said on Tuesday, in what would be a major step in arming Kyiv in its efforts to seize back its territory from Russia.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Natural Gas Shortages Hit China as Temperatures Plunge
articles.snippet: Local governments starved for cash after enormous spending on costly “zero Covid” measures cannot afford to keep up adequate supplies of gas.
articles.abstract: Local governments starved for cash after enormous spending on costly “zero Covid” measures cannot afford to keep up adequate supplies of gas.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many people across China, a shortage of natural gas and alarmingly cold temperatures are making a difficult winter unbearable. For Li Yongqiang, they mean freezing nights without heat.

articles.headline: Everyone Wants Your Email Address. Think Twice Before Sharing It.
articles.snippet: Your email address has become a digital bread crumb for companies to link your activity across sites. Here’s how you can limit this.
articles.abstract: Your email address has become a digital bread crumb for companies to link your activity across sites. Here’s how you can limit this.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you browse the web, an increasing number of sites and apps are asking for a piece of basic information that you probably hand over without hesitation: your email address.

articles.headline: Laid Off in Your Living Room: The Chaos of Remote Job Cuts
articles.snippet: Angst rippled across laptop screens this month, with dozens of companies announcing layoffs and finding ways to breed extra chaos in the process.
articles.abstract: Angst rippled across laptop screens this month, with dozens of companies announcing layoffs and finding ways to breed extra chaos in the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kerensa Cadenas opened Slack on Friday morning to an expletive-laden message from a colleague that said essentially: “I got let go.” Ms. Cadenas, steeling herself, checked her email. Then she typed out her own expletive. She’d been laid off, too. Alone in her Brooklyn apartment.

articles.headline: Climate Change May Usher in a New Era of Trade Wars
articles.snippet: Countries are pursuing new solutions to try to mitigate climate change. More trade fights are likely to come hand in hand.
articles.abstract: Countries are pursuing new solutions to try to mitigate climate change. More trade fights are likely to come hand in hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Efforts to mitigate climate change are prompting countries across the world to embrace dramatically different policies toward industry and trade, bringing governments into conflict.

articles.headline: 2023’s Biggest, Most Unusual Race Centers on Abortion and Democracy
articles.snippet: The election for a swing seat on Wisconsin’s Supreme Court has huge policy stakes for the battleground state. Cash is pouring in, and some of the candidates have shed any pretense of judicial neutrality.
articles.abstract: The election for a swing seat on Wisconsin’s Supreme Court has huge policy stakes for the battleground state. Cash is pouring in, and some of the candidates have shed any pretense of judicial neutrality.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 10 weeks, Wisconsin will hold an election that carries bigger policy stakes than any other contest in America in 2023.

articles.headline: Amid a Plague of Shootings, Bystanders Become Heroes
articles.snippet: Civilians, armed or not, have put their bodies on the line to stop gunmen. But in a nation trained to “Run, Hide, Fight,” many say it should never have come to that.
articles.abstract: Civilians, armed or not, have put their bodies on the line to stop gunmen. But in a nation trained to “Run, Hide, Fight,” many say it should never have come to that.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith, Eliza Fawcett and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: In U.K. Cost-of-Living Crisis, Some Workers Struggle to Feed Children
articles.snippet: As inflation hits the pockets of families who already had little to spare, food banks say they are getting much busier and seeing more people with jobs.
articles.abstract: As inflation hits the pockets of families who already had little to spare, food banks say they are getting much busier and seeing more people with jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: When her two sons ask for snacks she can no longer afford, Aislinn Corey, a preschool teacher in London, lays down a blanket on the floor and plays “the picnic game.” She takes an orange or an apple collected from her preschool’s food bank and slices it in thirds to be shared.
